description: 17th century; from flim-flam, itself perhaps from a dialectal word or Scandinavian; compare Old Norse flim (“lampoon, mockery”).

entries.meaning: A freak or whim; an idle fancy.
(archaic) A falsehood; a lie; an illusory pretext

verbs.description: flam (third-person singular simple present flams, present participle flamming, simple past and past participle flammed)

entries.meaning: (drumming) Two taps (a grace note followed by a full-volume tap) played very close together in order to sound like one slightly longer note.

verbs.description: flam (third-person singular simple present flams, present participle flamming, simple past and past participle flammed)

entries.meaning: (drumming, transitive, intransitive) To play (notes as) a flam.
examples: We will commence to flam the notes now, as most of them are flammed when you play a March.
